item.title: CoD: Black Ops 6 Zombies - How To Earn The Culinary Delight Achievement/Trophy
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cod-black-ops-6-zombies-how-to-earn-the-culinary-delight-achievement-and-trophy/1100-6527437/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6's Zombies mode features plenty of interesting secrets to uncover, including this cooking-related Easter egg that unlocks a hidden trophy/achievement. Here's how to unlock the Culinary Delight achievement on the Terminus map.

Collect cooking ingredients

From the starting area, you'll want to work towards the map's objective of turning on the power. While you're at the generator inside Living Quarters, go upstairs to the refrigerator. On top of the fridge is something that looks like a snowball, but it might actually be a pile of salt. Grab it.

Then continue following the steps for power, but stop when you reach the Engineering room. Go inside Engineering, and grab a battery item off a table with radios.

Cross over to the next building which is the Mess Hall. Collect a can of chili from the boxes of cabbages in the corner and cooking oil from the shelves by the kitchen.

Finish powering up the map and activating Pack-a-Punch at the Bio Lab, if you haven't completed these steps yet. Then, search the medical desks stationed around the Bio Lab until you find a brain. It should be a desk near Speed Cola. Collect the brain.

Also while you're in the Bio Lab, you can watch the water for splashes. Throw your lethal equipment into the water where you see a splash to kill a fish. Cooked grenades, semtex, and shock charges all work here. You can do this anywhere there's water, so it doesn't have to be at the Bio Lab. It's just more convenient.

Grab a dead fish. This part can be confusing, because it doesn't highlight or tell you that it's an item you can pick up. The fish won't even disappear like you collected it, but you should have one if you interact with it.

Now you have all the ingredients needed to cook.

Cook up a special dish

Head back to Mess Hall. Interact with the cooking pan on the stove. This lets you add all the ingredients to the pan one by one:

  • Cooking oil
  • Fish
  • Battery
  • Salt
  • Brain
  • Can of chili

Note: The trophy doesn't specify which items to use. The combined ingredients seems to be the salt, cooking oil, brain, and the battery, plus one other special ingredient. I've heard some people used eggplant instead of chili, but this is what worked for me.

The Culinary Delight trophy/achievement may not pop until you advance to the next round.

Zombies also features a supervillain-themed Easter egg on Liberty Falls that will reward you with another hidden achievement for Black Ops 6. Here are all the steps for completing the World Domination achievement.

For more on Zombies, check out our full guide on custom Zombies loadouts. Here you can find the steps to unlock the Easter egg songs for Liberty Falls and Terminus.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: CoD: Black Ops 6 Zombies - How To Become Superpowered And Earn World Domination Achievement/Trophy
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cod-black-ops-6-zombies-how-to-become-superpowered-and-earn-world-domination-achievement-and-trophy/1100-6527436/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6's Zombies mode features plenty of interesting side Easter eggs to uncover, including this supervillain-themed quest that unlocks a hidden trophy/achievement. Here's how to become a villain and unlock the World Domination achievement in Black Ops 6.

How to become Aetherella in Liberty Falls

Liberty Falls features its own fictional supervillain named Aetherella, who can also be seen as a statue inside the map's comic book shop. You can use this Aetherella statue as a trap for killing zombies, which beams them with laser eyes like Homelander from The Boys.

Aetherella also has nine action figures hidden around the map, and collecting them all will temporarily transform into the villain to use her superpower against the horde. This will also earn you the Black Ops 6 trophy/achievement called World Domination.

Craft a Jetgun Wonder Weapon

To start this side Easter egg, you'll first need to get your hands on the map's Wonder Weapon. This is a re-vamped version of the Jetgun from Black Ops 2's TranZit map.

There are a few steps needed for this, but we have a full guide on how to craft the Jetgun here. Alternatively, you can also get lucky and get the Jetgun from the Mystery Box, but your chances are slim.

Collect all nine Aetherella action figures

Using the Jetgun's sucking mechanic, you'll be able to reach Aetherella's out-of-reach action figures. These can be collected in any order.

One figure is found on top of the motel sign that's mounted to the right side of the building.

Another is found on top of the bowling alley. It's sitting on the ledge in front of the giant Liberty Falls sign.

Go on top of the bank roof, and look down at the video rental shop rooftop that's next to the motel. There's a figure tucked between the two AC units.

Climb on top of the small rooftop that leads to the bank roof. Turn and face the water tower and there is a figure on the AC unit mounted to the neighboring building.

Stand in front of the church and look up. There's a figure in the top-right window at the front of the church.

There are four figures to collect in the comic book shop:

  • One on the left side table when you enter the side door
  • Another is on a top shelf that's between some posters
  • One next to the Aetherella statue
  • A fourth is standing on the window-sill bench

You'll transform into Aetherella once you've collected all nine. I'd recommend waiting to collect the last one at the start of a new round. This gives you plenty of opportunity to make use of this powerful but limited superpower.

For more on Zombies, check out our full guide on custom Zombies loadouts. Here you can find the steps to unlock the Easter egg songs for Liberty Falls and Terminus.

The full guide to completing the Liberty Falls main quest can be found here. If you're an achievement hunter, there's a BO6 cooking-themed trophy/achievement that can be unlocked on the Terminus map.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Gets First Discount For PS5 And Xbox Series X
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/warhammer-40000-space-marine-2-gets-first-discount-for-ps5-and-xbox-series-x/1100-6527429/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2, one of the most popular and best action games of the year, has just received a nice discount on PS5 and Xbox Series X. Space. Marine 2 released in September with a $70 price point for consoles, $10 more than the PC edition. But now console players can dive into the action for $60, too. Amazon and Best Buy have discounted Space Marine 2 by 10 bucks for both PS5 and Xbox Series X.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Deals

$60 ($70)

  • Amazon: Space Marine 2 Deals
    • PS5
    • Xbox Series X
  • Best Buy: Space Marine 2 Deals
    • PS5
    • Xbox Series X

Like the original game published many years ago, Space Marine 2 goes all in on its action premise and Warhammer 40K setting. The best defense in the game is a good offense, and as a Primaris Space Marine, there's a gratifying amount of ultra-violence here as you carve a bloody path through the Tyranid hordes. The game looks good, feels consistently fun to play, and it has robust PvP and PvE modes to sample after the end credits have rolled on its meaty campaign.

"Space Marine 2 is a fantastic sequel that builds on its predecessor in every way, bombarding you with an overwhelming enemy and chaotic action that makes you feel like a small part of a much larger war," Richard Wakeling wrote in GameSpot's Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 review.

PC gamers aren't being left out in the cold either, as Space Marine 2 continues to be available for a discounted price at GameSpot sister site Fanatical. Currently, Fanatical is offering the standard version of the game for $52.79, the Gold Edition with the season pass for $79.19, and the Ultra Edition that throws in an Ultramarines Champion pack on top of all the other extras for $88.

Space Marine 2 PC Deals (Steam keys)

  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 -- $52.79 ($60)
  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2: Gold Edition -- $79.19 ($90)
  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2: Ultra Edition -- $88 ($100)

Space Marine 2 is just one of numerous recently released games on sale at Fanatical. Horror fans can save $15 on the brilliant Silent Hill 2 remake, an ideal choice during spooky season. Meanwhile, if you like turn-based RPGs, Atlus' new RPG Metaphor: ReFantazio is on sale for $9 off.

Warhammer 40,000: The Ultimate Guide releases this week

If you're currently playing Space Marine 2 and you're currently lost in a sea of lore, you can check out the Warhammer 40,000: The Ultimate Guide that launches this week (October 29). While it's challenging to sum up the lore and legends of the Warhammer 40K universe in a single book, this meaty encyclopedia sounds like a great way to get started on learning about this tabletop gaming giant, which has expanded into video games, books, and more mediums over the years. The book goes into exhaustive detail on the miniatures and stories of Warhammer 40,000, and it includes hundreds of photographs across 336 pages.

This is just the tip of the Warhammer 40K spear, and if you're looking to dive deep into the IP, you can check out GameSpot's detailed guide on where to start with Warhammer 40K's tabletop RPG, sprawling video game franchise, and hundreds of books.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: Make Sure To Check In On Your Old Portable Consoles For Swollen Batteries
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/make-sure-to-check-in-on-your-old-portable-consoles-for-swollen-batteries/1100-6527434/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Older console maintenance is a must-do habit for collectors to keep on playing their favorite games. From more difficult tasks like soddering in circuits to exponentially easier ones like replacing a battery, it's all part of keeping consoles up and running. The latter though, is something becoming more prominent over the last few years, especially with portable consoles using lithium batteries.

Earlier in October, some Twitter users found out that lithium batteries tend to swell up after a few years, potentially causing serious trouble. Now, this is not the first time this sort of incident has come up. The Playstation Vita had a similar situation, and even people reported PSP issues a few years ago.

"If you own any lipo battery I recommend buying yourself a lipo safe bag that is fire and explosion proof. I own a few of these and you never know when your batteries will burst due to swelling," one poster suggested. "You may just save your home from a fire or worse by spending an extra $15-$20."

So while some gamers might be experiencing this for the first time, it's hardly some new or sudden threat. This is a wise practice to periodically follow as your devices continue to age. When you notice it, it's not always an immediate threat, but something to make sure gets replaced.

"Swelling certainly isn't good, and it's an indicator of decreased performance," said David Mitlin, a battery researcher and professor at the University of Texas at Austin, in an interview with the Washington Post about the subject. "But it doesn't instantly mean the battery is going to catch on fire."

The condition is caused by the gases created lithium ions flow from one end to the other, moving in the opposite direction when the battery is being used to power something. Those ions move through something called the electrolyte. As you keep charging and discharging the battery over time, the electrolyte begins to decompose and produce gases as a byproduct.

Mitlin continued with the fact that that not all rechargeable batteries are equal. Some big name companies invest even bigger money into researching and developing batteries that stall this decay. In the meantime, there are a few things to keep an eye on such as if the battery gets too hot and what the charge percentage is.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
